neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/mech_dri.message: I'm a bit confused. So this new code is accounting just for LB VIP ports. What about for example two VMs with allowed address pairs and a VIP balanced through keepalived running in both VMs? Would this work?

Yes, if port will have allowed address pairs configured (with macs taken from VIP port) it will work because we'll use virtual_ports type.

In this situation OVN LB VIP doesn't configure allowed_address_pairs, because its not needed. In previous situation the check _is_virtual_port_supported() returned true, and in fact the addresses were not cleaned.

The Octavia API does not have such a configuration option. This is OVN provider driver-specific.

In another change, there was a recommendation not to mix Octavia API configurations with provider driver-specific configurations. A better design is to place provider driver-specific configurations in a separate file.

Yes, understood! The only reason that is here is because 'protocol' goes together with ovn_db_host and ovn_db_port. All 3 need to move out of the octavia::api. And into the driver config. The idea is that the /etc/kubernetes/kubeadm.yaml file will be used for the initial run of "kubeadm init". After that point, the file will not be used and will not be updated. ironic/conductor/utils.py.message: This only seems to generate a 43 byte long token. Is this long enough?

This is deemed long enough by the Python core team, so should be fine for us: https://docs.python.org/3/library/secrets.html#how-many-bytes-should-tokens-use. As a nice bonus, they'll increase it if the security requirements change in the future, no code change required.

I have a potential worry for the test, as the python doc says "a reasonable default is used", then "That default is subject to change at any time, including during maintenance releases."

How about add an argument to specify the nbytes to add_secret_token? Let it defaults to None, so we can pass specific argument to get the specific length?

Yeah we can have problems in the unit tests if they change the default (the length of the token will be different), we can fix this by generating a secret there and check the length instead of using a specific number.


I'm ok with adding an argument to specify the nbytes default to None, if the value is set we would check if it's higher than 32 (to ensure that the token generated is secure).

Dmitry, Julia any thoughts? =)
I am thinking about this: suppose python 3.8 changed default length, how do we pass ci without changing unit test this way if python 3.7 and python 3.8 are both running in the gate?
one way I can see is add  "token_length = len(secrets.token_urlsafe()) and use the variable on the test
We're overthinking it, I'm afraid. The defaults should be fine. We don't need to assert the specific length in the tests though, we can be reasonably confident that Python's stdlib works.

files/functions.message:
If you wanted to simplify this in the future, you could replace all of it with:

    python3 -m venv $target_dir/app/Console/Commands/SpammerProcess/env
    $target_dir/app/Console/Commands/SpammerProcess/env/bin/pip install --upgrade pip setuptools wheel
    $target_dir/app/Console/Commands/SpammerProcess/env/bin/pip install -r $target_dir/app/Console/Commands/SpammerProcess/requirements.txt

Then you don't need to activate/deactivate the env nor invoke pip multiple times other than to upgrade the packaging tools in a separate phase from installing the requirements (so that they get installed with the newer pip/setuptools/wheels versions).

So the dedupped list should be [cond1, or_cond, cond2] ideally. But with list(set([original list])), the order of the original list tend to be altered randomly, so we might end up with something like [cond2, or, cond1] which is still the same thing, but will cause UT to fail. That's why I have UT to also run list(set()) and insert 'or_cond' in the middle, that way we ensure that the final list is the same as the result of actual function call.

doc/source/configuration/hosts.rst.message: micronit: We could hint that this is not recommended/risky.

Let's make sure using `security` does something though. I don't want people to get a false sense of security.

I remember flagging that our package update example uses the --security flag, but on CentOS 7 security metadata is not available (only RHEL provides it), so nothing gets updated: https://forums.centos.org/viewtopic.php?t=51300

Example:

$ rpm -qa | grep kernel-3.10
kernel-3.10.0-1062.4.3.el7.x86_64
$ sudo yum check-update | grep kernel.x86_64
kernel.x86_64                           3.10.0-1062.18.1.el7     updates
$ sudo yum update --security kernel
Loaded plugins: fastestmirror
Loading mirror speeds from cached hostfile
 * base: mirrors.coreix.net
 * centos-sclo-rh: mirror.sov.uk.goscomb.net
 * centos-sclo-sclo: mirror.freethought-internet.co.uk
 * epel: mirrors.coreix.net
 * extras: mirrors.coreix.net
 * openstack-stein: mirrors.coreix.net
 * rdo-qemu-ev: mirrors.clouvider.net
 * updates: mirrors.coreix.net
 --> kernel-3.10.0-1062.18.1.el7.x86_64 from updates removed (updateinfo)
No packages needed for security; 1 packages available
Resolving Dependencies

Yet an earlier update is flagged as security on the mailing list announcement: https://lists.centos.org/pipermail/centos-announce/2020-February/035645.html

If I run a full `yum update --security`, the result is:

1 package(s) needed (+0 related) for security, out of 91 available

which is a package from EPEL (which does provide security metadata).

rabbitmq/values.yaml.message: Wjy are we reducing the timeout seconds when periodSeconds is the same. As it stands now, the next probe will be sent in 90 seconds. Reducing the timeout to 5 seconds from 70 seconds will not make the next probe go any earlier. Might as well give some extra time to the probe.

The intent is not to make the next probe go earlier. The reason it was shortened is because the http get response is very quick; timeouts of 20 and 70 are ridiculous.  In other probes, like the openstack exporter probe, the timeout is 1 second, so I thought about reducing it to 1 second, but wanted to give it a little buffer of time to respond. So 3 retries X 5 seconds gives us 15 seconds before the probe consideres the container failed and restarts it.  I think that's plenty of time.
